ContentClassification.TableReference: Continuous Mortality Investigation “Assured Lives 1944-48”, Journal of the Institute of Actuaries, Vol. 77 No. 1,Institute and Faculty of Actuaries, Cambridge University Press, (1951). Accessed: August, 2014 from http://www.actuaries.org.uk/sites/all/files/documents/pdf/0103-0119.pdf
ContentClassification.TableDescription: A1947-48 Mortality Table for Assured Lives. Minimum Age: 20. Maximum Age: 100.
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: Experience from offices writing standard assured lives in the United Kingdom and who submit data to the Continuous Mortality Investigation. As little difference in mortality was seen between the non-medical class and the medical class was seen, they were combined. Although data was collected for the period 1944-48, the last two years of this period represent data free of war mortality and thus afford the opportunity of assessing the effects on assured lives experience. Methodology: In order to give some general indication of the current level of the mortality of assured lives, the data for the tow years 1947-1948, for all classes of business at durations 3 and over, have been combined and a set of mortality rates has been derived. The rates were graduated by Spencer’s 21-term formula, with adjustments at the young and old ages. Data Transcription Errors: None. Data Certified: 08/2014.

MetaData.TableDescription: A1947-48 Mortality Table for Assured Lives. Minimum Age: 20. Maximum Age: 100.
